courses.name: Intermediate Algebra
courses.description: MATH _0110 is a preparatory course for college algebra that carries no credit towards any baccalaureate degree.  However, the grade received in MATH _0110 does count towards a student's overall GPA.  The course covers operations with real numbers, graphs of functions, domain and range of functions, linear equations and inequalities, quadratic equations; operations with polynomials, rational expressions, exponents and radicals; equations of lines.  Emphasis is also put on problem-solving.

courses.name: Quantitative Reasoning
courses.description: Promotes mathematical literacy among students. This course will cover important mathematical ideas and problem solving skills in the context of science, technology, and/or society. Topics may include: logic and critical thinking, Venn Diagrams, problem solving, sets, units of measure, percentages and ratios, counting and probability, exponential growth and decay, linear and exponential models. Quantitative Reasoning is designed to stimulate interest in and appreciation of mathematics and quantitative reasoning as valuable tools for comprehending the world in which we live. This course does not satisfy the prerequisite of any other math course.
courses.prerequisites: C- or higher in MATH _0110 or a sufficient score on the ALEKS (or MMT) exam

courses.name: College Algebra
courses.description: A review of exponents, order of operations, factoring, and simplifying polynomial, rational, and radical expressions. Topics include: linear, quadratic, polynomial, rational, inverse, exponential, and logarithmic functions and their applications. Students will solve equations involving these functions, and systems of linear equations in two variables, as well as inequalities.  See the Math website for specific requirements.  A student may receive at most 5.0 credit hours among MATH 1100, MATH 1120, MATH 1140, MATH 1160.
courses.prerequisites: C- or higher in MATH _0110 or a sufficient score on the ALEKS exam or MyMathTest Intermediate Algebra score of 70% or higher

courses.name: Trigonometry
courses.description: A student may receive only 5 credits from among MATH 1100, MATH 1140, and MATH 1160. A Student may receive at most 5.0 credit hours from MATH 1100, MATH 1120, MATH 1140, and MATH 1160.
courses.prerequisites: C- or higher in MATH 1100 or sufficient ALEKS score or MyMathTest College Algebra score of 70% or higher

courses.name: Precalculus Mathematics
courses.description: Review of elementary algebra. Background material for MATH 1500, including algebraic, trigonometric, logarithmic, exponential functions.  A student may receive at most 5 credits from among MATH 1100, MATH 1140, and MATH 1160.
courses.prerequisites: B+ or higher in MATH _0110 (at MU), or C- or higher in  MATH 1100, or sufficient ALEKS score or MyMathTest College Algebra score of 60% or higer

courses.name: Finite Mathematics
courses.description: A selections of topics in finite mathematics such as: basic financial mathematics, counting methods and basic probability and statistics, systems of linear equations and matrices.  Warning: without a College Algebra exemption, a sufficient ALEKS score will not suffice unless it is a proctored exam (for MATH 1100 credit).
courses.prerequisites: Grade of C- or higher in MATH 1100, or MATH 1160, or both a College Algebra exemption and sufficient ALEKS score

courses.name: Elements of Calculus
courses.description: Introductory analytic geometry, derivatives, definite integrals. Primarily for Computer Science BA candidates, Economics majors, and students preparing to enter the College of BUS. No credit for students who have completed a calculus course.  A student may receive credit for MATH 1320, or MATH 1400 but not both.  A student may receive at most 5 credit hours among MATH 1320 or MATH 1400 or MATH 1500.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 1100, or MATH 1160, or sufficient ALEKS score

courses.name: Geometric Concepts
courses.description: This course is primarily for education majors. This course covers topics of Euclidean geometry such as the study of points, lines, angles, polygons, circles, congruence, similarity, transformations, symmetry, area, surface area, arc length, and volume. Polyhedra, spheres, cones, and other solids are discussed. The course includes constructions and proofs, and uses inductive and deductive reasoning throughout.  Math Reasoning Proficiency Course.
courses.prerequisites: C- or higher in MATH 1100 or sufficient ALEKS exam score or MATH 1160 or equivalent

courses.name: Calculus for Social and Life Sciences I
courses.description: The real number system, functions, analytic geometry, derivatives, integrals, maximum-minimum problems. No credit for students who have completed a calculus course.   A student may receive credit for MATH 1320 or MATH 1400 but not both.  A student may receive at most 5 units of credit among the MATH 1320 or MATH 1400 and MATH 1500.  Math Reasoning Proficiency Course.
courses.prerequisites: grade of C- or higher in MATH 1100, or MATH 1160, or sufficient ALEKS score

courses.name: Analytic Geometry and Calculus I
courses.description: Elementary analytic geometry, functions, limits, continuity, derivatives, antiderivatives, definite integrals.  A student may receive at most 5 units of credit among the Mathematics courses MATH 1320 or MATH 1400 and MATH 1500. Math Reasoning Proficiency Course.
courses.prerequisites: grade of C- or higher in MATH 1160 or C - or higher in both MATH 1100 and MATH 1140 or sufficient ALEKS score or MyMathTest PreCalculus score of 70% or higher

courses.name: Analytic Geometry and Calculus I - Honors
courses.description: Elementary analytic geometry, functions, limits, continuity, derivatives, antiderivatives, definite integrals.   Honors eligibility required.   A student may receive at most 5 units of credit among  MATH 1320 or MATH 1400 and MATH 1500. Math Reasoning Proficiency course.
courses.prerequisites: C- or higher  in MATH 1160 or C- in  both MATH 1100 and MATH 1140 and sufficient ALEKS score.  Honors Eligibility required

courses.name: Selected Topics in Mathematics-General
courses.description: The special topics covered may vary from term to term. This course may be repeated.

courses.name: Selected Topics in Mathematics-Biological/Physical/Math
courses.description: The special topics covered may vary from term to term. This course may be repeated.

courses.name: Calculus II
courses.description: Definite integrals, applications and techniques of integration, elementary transcendental functions, infinite series.  Math Proficiency Reasoning course.
courses.prerequisites: a grade of C- or better in MATH 1500

courses.name: Calculus II - Honors
courses.description: Definite integrals, applications and techniques of integration, elementary transcendental functions, infinite series.  Math Reasoning Proficiency course.
courses.prerequisites: a grade of C- or better in MATH 1500. Honors eligibility required

courses.name: Introduction to Analysis I
courses.description: This course will cover the material taught in a traditional first semester calculus course at a more rigorous level. The focus of this course will be on proofs of basic theorems of differential and integral calculus.  The topics to be covered include axioms of arithmetic, mathematical induction, functions, graphs, limits, continuous functions, derivatives and their applications, integrals, the fundamental theorem of calculus and trigonometric functions. Students in this class will be expected to learn to write clear proofs of mathematical assertions.  Some previous exposure to calculus is helpful but not required.  No credit for  MATH 1800 and MATH 1320, MATH 1400 or MATH 1500.  Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: ACT mathematics score of at least 31 and ACT composite of at least 30 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Introduction to Analysis II
courses.description: This course is a continuation of MATH 1800.  In this course we shall cover uniform convergence and uniform continuity, integration, and sequences and series.  The topics will be covered in a mathematically rigourous manner.  No credit for MATH 1900 and MATH 1700 or MATH 2100.  Graded on A/F basis only.

courses.name: Calculus for Social and Life Sciences II
courses.description: Riemann integral, transcendental functions, techniques of integration, improper integrals and functions of several variables. No credit for students who have completed two calculus courses.  Math Reasoning Proficiency course.
courses.prerequisites: C- or higher in  MATH 1320 or MATH 1400 or MATH 1500

courses.name: Geometric Axioms and Structures
courses.description: Euclidean Geometry, Axiom systems, spherical geometry, finite geometries, and explorations with technology.

courses.name: Calculus III
courses.description: Vectors, solid analytic geometry, calculus of several variables.  Math Reasoning Proficiency course.
courses.prerequisites: grade of C- or better in MATH 1700

courses.name: Calculus III - Honors
courses.description: Vectors, solid analytic geometry, calculus of several variables.  Math Reasoning Proficiency course.
courses.prerequisites: grade of C or better in MATH 1700. Honors eligibility required

courses.name: Discrete Mathematical Structures
courses.description: Sets, functions, logic, relations, induction, recursion, counting techniques, graphs, trees, algorithms.  Math Reasoning Proficiency course.
courses.prerequisites: Grade of C- or higher in MATH 1700

courses.name: Algebraic Structures
courses.description: Introduction to axiomatic mathematics with emphasis on rings and groups. Applications to elementary number theory.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 1300 and MATH 1320 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Introduction to Advanced Mathematics
courses.description: Gateway to theoretical math courses.  Focus on reading and writing math proofs/rigorously developing background needed in Adv Calc/Abstract Alg.  Topics include logic, set theory, properties of functions and integers, the real number system, completeness of the real numbers, sequences of real numbers.
courses.prerequisites: Consent of Department required.   Recommended MATH 1700

courses.name: Introduction to Advanced Mathematics - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Gateway to theoretical math courses.  Focus on reading and writing math proofs/rigorously developing background needed in Adv Calc/Abstract Alg.  Topics include logic, set theory, properties of functions and integers, the real number system, completeness of the real numbers, sequences of real numbers.
courses.prerequisites: Consent of Department required.   Recommended MATH 1700

courses.name: Topics in Mathematics-General
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics. Subjects and earnable credit may vary from semester to semester.  May repeat for credit with Departmental consent.
courses.prerequisites: Grade of C- of higher in MATH 2300

courses.name: Topics in Mathematics-Biological/Physical/Math
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics. Subjects and earnable credit may vary from semester to semester.  May repeat for credit with Departmental consent.

courses.name: Connecting Geometry to Middle and Secondary Schools
courses.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 7060). Euclidean foundations, logic, Euler Characteristic, congruence, area, Pick's Theorem, volume, Cavalieri's Principle, surface area, similarity, symmetry, transformations, matricies, introduction to spherical geometry.

courses.name: Connecting Algebra to Middle and Secondary Schools
courses.description: A detailed study of integer and rational arithmetic and algebra.  Topics include: Bionomial Theorem, induction, division algorithm, Euclid's Algorithm, Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic, Pythogorian triples, modular arithmetic and generalizations to polynomials, matrices and other axiomatic structures.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 1320, enrollment is restricted to Math Education majors

courses.name: Calculus Connections
courses.description: Course topics include: sequences, series, functions, limits, continuity, differentiation, optimization, curve sketching, antidifferentiation, areas of plane regions, lengths of plane curves, areas of surfaces of revolution, and volumes of solids.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 1160, enrollment is restricted to Math Education majors

courses.name: Differential Equations
courses.description: Traditional introductory course in ordinary differential equations. Includes 1st and 2nd order linear differential equations with numerous applications; Laplace transforms; power series solutions; numerical methods, linear systems.
courses.prerequisites: Grade of C- or above in MATH 2300

courses.name: Advanced Calculus With Applications
courses.description: Linear mappings, Jacobi matrices and determinants, change of variables, vector fields, line and surface integrals, theorems of Green, Gauss and Stokes, sequences and series of functions, uniform convergence, special functions.

courses.name: Combinatorics
courses.description: Study of a variety of topics from combinatorial mathematics, especially graph theory and enumerative combinatorics. Topics include graph coloring, matchings and coverings, generating functions, recurrence relations, Polya's Enumeration Theorem, introduction to Ramsey theory.

courses.name: Matrix Theory
courses.description: Basic properties of matrices, determinants, vector spaces, linear transformations, eigenvalues, eigenvectors, and Jordan normal forms. Introduction to writing proofs.
courses.prerequisites: Grade of C- or better in MATH 2300 or MATH 2320.  Writing intensive sections require ENGLSH 1000

courses.name: Matrix Theory - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Basic properties of matrices, determinants, vector spaces, linear transformations, eigenvalues, eigenvectors, and Jordan normal forms. Introduction to writing proofs.
courses.prerequisites: Grade of C- or better in MATH 2300 or MATH 2320.  Writing intensive sections require ENGLSH 1000

courses.name: History of Mathematics
courses.description: This is a history course with mathematics as its subject. Includes topics in the history of mathematics from early civilizations onwards.  The growth of mathematics, both as an abstract discipline and as a subject which interacts with others and with practical concerns, is explored.  Prerequisites or Cirequisite:  MATH 2300 or MATH 2340.  Writing intensive sections require ENGLSH 1000.

courses.name: History of Mathematics - Writing Intensive
courses.description: This is a history course with mathematics as its subject. Includes topics in the history of mathematics from early civilizations onwards.  The growth of mathematics, both as an abstract discipline and as a subject which interacts with others and with practical concerns, is explored.  Prerequisites or Cirequisite:  MATH 2300 or MATH 2340.  Writing intensive sections require ENGLSH 1000.

courses.name: Numerical Analysis
courses.description: Machine arithmetic, approximation and interpolation, numerical differentiation and integration, nonlinear equations, linear systems, differential equations, error analysis. Selected algorithms will be programmed for solution on computers.
courses.prerequisites: Grade of C- or better in MATH 2300 and MATH 4100

courses.name: Numerical Linear Algebra
courses.description: Solution of linear systems of equations by direct and iterative methods. Calculation of eigenvalues and eigenvectors of matrices. Selected algorithms programmed for solution on computers.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 2300 and familiarity with software such as Mathematica, MatLab, Maple, etc

courses.name: Introduction to Mathematical Statistics
courses.description: (same as STAT 4710). Introduction to theory of probability and statistics using concepts and methods of calculus.

courses.name: Introduction to Probability Theory
courses.description: (same as STAT 4750). Probability spaces; random variables and their distributions; repeated trials; probability limit theorems.

courses.name: Linear Programming
courses.description: Linear dependence and rank in vector spaces in Rn, Farkas' Lemma, Polyhedral Decomposition. Strong duality and complementary theorems. The simplex method, revised simplex, and sensitivity analysis. Primal Dual simplex method and network simplex methods. Computational Complexity and Karmarkar's Algorithm.

courses.name: Theory of Numbers
courses.description: Divisibility, factorization, arithmetic functions, means value theorems, distribution of prime numbers, congruences, primitive roots, character theory, Riemann zeta function, and Dirichlet L-functions.
courses.prerequisites: Grade of C- or higher in MATH 2300. Recommended  MATH 2320

courses.name: College Geometry
courses.description: Euclidean geometry from an advanced viewpoint. Synthetic and coordinate methods will be used. The Euclidean group of transformations will be studied.

courses.name: Projective Geometry
courses.description: Basic ideas and methods of projective geometry built around the concept of geometry as the study of invariants of a group. Extensive treatment of collineations.

courses.name: Foundations of Geometry
courses.description: Coordination of affine, projective planes by means of various kinds of algebraic structures: planar ternary rings, Veblen-Wedderburn systems, divisions rings, skew fields, and fields.

courses.name: Introduction to Non-Euclidean Geometry
courses.description: Account of rise, development of non-Euclidean geometries. Intensive study of plane hyperbolic geometry.

courses.name: Introduction to Financial Derivatives and Options
courses.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 7355).  Long and short positions, forward contracts, exchange traded index futures, European and American call and put options, put-call parity, trading and hedging strategies, synthetic transactions, arbitrage, currency options, fixed income portfolio management, duration, convexity, interest rate and currency swaps, embedded options.
courses.prerequisites: Grade of C- or higher in  MATH 2300 and  either STAT 2500 or STAT 4710 or MATH 4315

courses.name: Actuarial Mathematics
courses.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 7360). Basic actuarial methods, mathematical population studies and models of population growth.  Compound interest and annuities certain.  Values of endowment and annuities, calculation of premiums, surrender values.  Stochastic models of populations growth.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 2300 and either STAT 2500 or STAT 4710 or MATH 4315

courses.name: Actuarial Modeling I
courses.description: This course covers the concepts underlying the theory of interest and their applications to valuation of various cash flows, annuities certain, bonds, and loan repayment.  This course is designed to help students prepare for Society of Actuaries exam FM (Financial Mathematics).  It is oriented towards problem solving techniques applied to real-life situations and illustrated with previous exam problems.
courses.prerequisites: grade of C-or better in MATH 2300

courses.name: Actuarial Modeling II
courses.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 7371). The goal of this course is to teach the basic theory of life contingent actuarial models and the application of those models to insurance and other financial risks.  The topics covered are part of the readings for the Society of Actuaries exam MLC (Models for Life Contingencies) and are illustrated with past exam questions.

courses.name: Introduction to Topology
courses.description: Topics from topology of Euclidean spaces, generalizations to metric spaces and topological spaces. Fundamentals of point set topology.

courses.name: Applied Analysis
courses.description: Solution of the standard partial differential equations (wave, heat, Laplace's eq.) by separation of variables and transform methods; including eigenfunction expansions, Fourier and Laplace transform. Boundary value problems, Sturm-Liouville theory, orthogonality, Fourier, Bessel, and Legendre series, spherical harmonics.
courses.prerequisites: Grade of C- or higher in MATH 4100

courses.name: Higher Algebra
courses.description: Introduction to rings, integral domains, fields, groups.
courses.prerequisites: Grade of C- or higher in MATH 2300 or MATH 2320

courses.name: Statistical Inference I
courses.description: (same as STAT  4760). Sampling; point estimation; sampling distribution; tests of hypotheses; regression and linear hypotheses.

courses.name: Mathematical Modeling I
courses.description: Solution of problems from industry, physical, social and life sciences, economics, and engineering using mathematical models.
courses.prerequisites: Grade of C- or higher in MATH 2300 and MATH 4100
courses.recommendation: Familiarity with software such as MATHEMATICA, MATLAB, or MAPLE

courses.name: Nonlinear Dynamics, Fractals and Chaos
courses.description: Conceptual introduction to nonlinear dynamics, bifurcation and stability of steady states, chaos in nonlinear differential equations and maps, fractal dimension, strange attractors, and applications to physical science.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 4100 or MATH 7100,  MATH 4140 or MATH 7140, and familiarity with software such as MATHEMATICA, MATLAB, or MAPLE

courses.name: Fluid Dynamics
courses.description: Mathematical theory of fluid dynamics and applications.

courses.name: Mathematical Modeling II
courses.description: Solution of problems from industry, physical, social and life sciences, economics, and engineering using mathematical models. More general classes of problems than in Mathematics 4540 will be considered.
courses.prerequisites: 3 semesters of calculus and some exposure to ordinary differential equations or instructor's consent.   MATH 4540 is not a prerequisite

courses.name: Mathematics of Financial Derivatives
courses.description: Binomial and Black-Scholes pricing models.Option Greeks, delta and gamma hedging, market maker profit theory.  Asian, barrier, compound gap and exchange options.  Lognormal and Monte Carlo price simulation.  Geometric Brownian Motion and Ito's Lemma.  Interest rate models and volatility.    Recommended: MATH 4355
courses.prerequisites: MATH 2300 and either STAT 2500 or STAT 4710 or MATH 4315

courses.name: Advanced Calculus of One Real Variable I
courses.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 7700). Basic topology of the real line, numerical sequences and series, continuity, differentiability, Riemann integration, uniform convergence, power series.
courses.prerequisites: Grade of C - or higher in MATH 3000

courses.name: Introduction to Abstract Algebra I
courses.description: Basic properties of integers, fundamental theorem of arithmetic, introduction to groups, rings and fields.
courses.prerequisites: Grade of C- or higher in MATH 3000

courses.name: Advanced Calculus for One Real Variable II
courses.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 7800). Continuation of Advanced Calculus for functions of a single real variable.  Topics include sequences and series of functions, power series and real analytic functions, Fourier series.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 4700 or MATH 7700 or permission of the instructor

courses.name: Advanced Multivariable Calculus
courses.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 7900). This is a course in calculus in several variables.  The following is core material:  Basic topology of n-dimensional Euclidian space; limits and continuity of functions; the derivative as a linear transformation; Taylor's formula with remainder; the Inverse and Implicit Function Theorems, change of coordinates; integration (including transformation of integrals under changes of coordinates); Green's Theorem. Additional material from the calculus of several variables may be included, such as Lagrange multipliers, differential forms, etc.

courses.name: Introduction to Abstract Linear Algebra
courses.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 7920). Study of vector spaces over arbitrary fields:  topics include linear maps on finite dimensional vector spaces, bilinear and multi-linear forms, invariant subspaces and canonical forms.
courses.prerequisites: Grade of C- or higher in  MATH 4720

courses.name: Introduction to Complex Variables
courses.description: Complex functions, contour integration, power series, residues and poles, conformal mapping.

courses.name: Senior Seminar in Mathematics
courses.description: Seminar with student presentations, written projects, and problem solving. May be used for the capstone requirement.

courses.name: Mathematics Problem Solving
courses.description: Creative advanced problem solving bringing together methods such as integration, probability and Euclidean geometry.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 4140 and another 4000 level Mathematics course, or instructor's consent

courses.name: Honors in Mathematics
courses.description: Special work for senior B.A. Honors and B.S. Honors candidates.

courses.name: Topics in Mathematics-General
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics. Subjects and earnable credit may vary from semester to semester.
courses.prerequisites: graduate standing and MATH 2300 and instructor's consent. Departmental consent for repetition

courses.name: Connecting Geometry to Middle and Secondary Schools
courses.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 4060). Euclidian foundations, basic concepts of symbolic logic, polyhedra, Euler Characteristic, congruence, area, Picks Theorem, volume, Cavalier's Principles, surface area, similarity, reflections, translations, rotations, symmetry, vectors, general transformations, determinants, matricies, transformations using matricies, brief introduction to spherical geometry.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 1360 or MATH 1500, enrollment is restricted to Math Education majors

courses.name: Connecting Algebra to Middle and Secondary Schools
courses.description: A detailed study of integer and rational arithmetic and algebra.  Topics include: Bionomial Theorem, induction, division algorithm, Euclid's Algorithm, Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic, Pythogorian triples, modular arithmetic and generalizations to polynomials, matrices and other axiomatic structures.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 1320, enrollment is restricted to Math Education majors

courses.name: Connect Calculus to Middle and Secondary Schools
courses.description: Course topics include: sequences, series functions, limits, continuity, differentiation, optimization, curve sketching, antidifferentiation, area of plane regions, lengths of plane curves, areas of surfaces of revolution, and volumes of solids,
courses.prerequisites: MATH 1160, enrollment is restricted to Math Education majors

courses.name: Differential Equations
courses.description: Traditional introductory course in ordinary differential equations. Includes 1st and 2nd order linear differential equations with numerous applications; Laplace transforms; power series solutions; numerical methods, linear systems.

courses.name: Advanced Calculus With Applications
courses.description: Linear mappings, Jacobi matrices and determinants, change of variables, vector fields, line and surface integrals, theorems of Green, Gauss and Stokes, sequences and series of functions, uniform convergence, special functions.

courses.name: Matrix Theory
courses.description: Basic properties of matrices, determinants, vector spaces, linear transformations, eigenvalues, eigenvectors, and Jordan normal forms. Introduction to writing proofs.
courses.prerequisites: graduate standing and one of MATH 2300, MATH 2320, MATH 2120 or  MATH 2340

courses.name: History of Mathematics
courses.description: This is a history course with mathematics as its subject. Includes topics in the history of mathematics from early civilizations onwards.  The growth of mathematics, both as an abstract discipline and as a subject which interacts with others and with practical concerns, is explored.  Pre- or Co-requisite: MATH 2300 or MATH  2340 and graduate standing.

courses.name: Numerical Analysis
courses.description: Machine arithmetic, approximation and interpolation, numerical differentiation and integration, nonlinear equations, linear systems, differential equations, error analysis. Selected algorithms will be programmed for solution on computers.
courses.prerequisites: graduate standing and MATH 2300 and MATH 4100 or equivalent

courses.name: Numerical Linear Algebra
courses.description: Solution of linear systems of equations by direct and iterative methods. Calculation of eigenvalues and eigenvectors of matrices. Selected algorithms programmed for solution on computers.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 2300 and prior experience writing programs in Mathematica and /or in a computer language such as Fortran, Pascal, or C

courses.name: Introduction to Mathematical Statistics
courses.description: (same as STAT 7710). Introduction to theory of probability and statistics using concepts and methods of calculus.
courses.prerequisites: graduate standing and MATH 2300 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Introduction to Probability Theory
courses.description: (same as STAT 7750). Probability spaces; random variables and their distributions; repeated trials; probability limit theorems.

courses.name: Theory of Numbers
courses.description: Divisibility, factorization, arithmetic functions, means value theorems, distribution of prime numbers, congruences, primitive roots, character theory, Riemann zeta function, and Dirichlet L-functions.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 2300; recommended MATH 2320 or MATH 2340, and MATH 4940 or MATH 7940

courses.name: College Geometry
courses.description: Euclidean geometry from an advanced viewpoint. Synthetic and coordinate methods will be used. The Euclidean group of transformations will be studied.

courses.name: Projective Geometry
courses.description: Basic ideas and methods of projective geometry built around the concept of geometry as the study of invariants of a group. Extensive treatment of collineations.

courses.name: Foundations of Geometry
courses.description: Coordination of affine, projective planes by means of various kinds of algebraic structures: planar ternary rings, Veblen-Wedderburn systems, divisions rings, skew fields, and fields.

courses.name: Introduction to Non-Euclidean Geometry
courses.description: Account of rise, development of non-Euclidean geometries. Intensive study of plane hyperbolic geometry.

courses.name: Introduction to Financial Derivatives and Options
courses.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 4355).  Long and short positions, forward contracts, exchange traded index futures, European and American call and put options, put-call parity, trading and hedging strategies, synthetic transactions, arbitrage, currency options, fixed income portfolio management, duration, convexity, interest rate and currency swaps, embedded options.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 2300 and STAT 2500 or STAT 4710/ MATH 4315, or instructor's consent

courses.name: Actuarial Mathematics
courses.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 4360). Basic actuarial methods, mathematical population studies and models of population growth.  Compound interest and annuities certain.  Values of endowment and annuities, calculation of premiums, surrender values.  Stochastic models of populations growth.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 2300 and either STAT 2500 or STAT 4710/ MATH 4315, or instructor's consent

courses.name: Actuarial Modeling I
courses.description: This course covers the main probability tools applied to financial risk modeling, and the financial mathematics concepts used in calculating present and accumulated values for various cash flows.  It is a helpful tool in preparing for the Society of Actuaries exams P (Probability) and FM (Financial Mathematics), and it is oriented towards problem solving techniques illustrated with previous exam problems.  Students are encouraged to take MATH 4355 prior to this course.

courses.name: Actuarial Modeling II
courses.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 4371). The goal of this course is to teach the basic theory of life contingent actuarial models and the application of those models to insurance and other financial risks.  The topics covered are part of the readings for the Society of Actuaries exam MLC (Models for Life Contingencies) and are illustrated with past exam questions.

courses.name: Introduction to Topology
courses.description: Topics from topology of Euclidean spaces, generalizations to metric spaces and topological spaces. Fundamentals of point set topology.

courses.name: Applied Analysis
courses.description: Solution of the standard partial differential equations (wave, heat, Laplace's eq.) by separation of variables and transform methods; including eigenfunction expansions, Fourier and Laplace transform. Boundary value problems, Sturm-Liouville theory, orthogonality, Fourier, Bessel, and Legendre series, spherical harmonics.

courses.name: Higher Algebra
courses.description: Introduction to rings, integral domains, fields, groups.

courses.name: Statistical Inference I
courses.description: (same as STAT 7760). Sampling; point estimation; sampling distribution; tests of hypotheses; regression and linear hypotheses.

courses.name: Mathematical Modeling I
courses.description: Solution of problems from industry, physical, social and life sciences, economics, and engineering using mathematical models.
courses.prerequisites: graduate standing and 3 semesters of calculus and some exposure to ordinary differential equations or instructor's consent

courses.name: Nonlinear Dynamics, Chaos and Fractals
courses.description: Conceptual introduction to nonlinear dynamics, bifurcation and stability of steady states, chaos in nonlinear differential equations and maps, fractal dimension, strange attractors, and applications to physical science.
courses.prerequisites: graduate standing and MATH 4100/ MATH 7100, MATH 4140/ MATH 7140, and familiarity with software such as MATHEMATICA, MATLAB, or MAPLE

courses.name: Fluid Dynamics and Geophysical Applications
courses.description: Mathematical theory of fluid dynamics and applications to meteorology and oceanography.

courses.name: Mathematical Modeling II
courses.description: Solution of problems from industry, physical, social and life sciences, economics, and engineering using mathematical models. More general classes of problems than in MATH 7540 will be considered.
courses.prerequisites: 3 semesters of calculus and some exposure to ordinary differential equations or instructor's consent.MATH 7540 is not a prerequisite

courses.name: Mathematics of Financial Derivatives
courses.description: Binomial and Black-Scholes pricing models.Option Greeks, delta and gamma hedging, market maker profit theory.  Asian, barrier, compound, gap and exchange options.  Lognormal and Monte Carlo price simulation.  Geometric Brownian Motion and Ito's Lemma.  Interest rate models and volatility.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 2300 and either STAT 2500 or STAT 4710 or MATH 4315

courses.name: Differential Geometry I
courses.description: Metric properties of restricted portions of curves and surfaces in three-dimensional Euclidean space.

courses.name: Advanced Calculus of One Real Variable I
courses.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 4700). Series of real numbers, limits of functions, continuity and uniform continuity, differentiability, and Riemann integration.
courses.recommendation: MATH 4140 and one other mathematics course number above MATH 2300

courses.name: Introduction to Abstract Algebra I
courses.description: Basic properties of integers, fundamental theorem of arithmetic, introduction to groups, rings and fields.
courses.recommendation: MATH 4140 and one other Mathematics course numbered above 2300

courses.name: Advanced Calculus of One Real Variable II
courses.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 4800). Continuation of Advanced Calculus for functions of a single real variable.  Topics include sequences and series of functions, power series and real analytic functions, Fourier series.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 4700 or MATH 7700 or permission of the instructor

courses.name: Advanced Multivariable Calculus
courses.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 4900). This is a course in calculus in several variables.  The following is core material:  Basic topology of n-dimensional Euclidian space; limits and continuity of functions; the derivative as a linear transformation; Taylor's formula with remainder; the Inverse and Implicit Function Theorems, change of coordinates; integration (including transformation of integrals under changes of coordinates); Green's Theorem. Additional material from the calculus of several variables may be included, such as Lagrange multipliers, differential forms, etc.

courses.name: Introduction to Abstract Linear Algebra
courses.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 4920). Study of vector spaces over arbitrary fields:  topics include linear maps on finite dimensional vector spaces, bilinear and multi-linear forms, invariant subspaces and canonical forms.

courses.name: Introduction to Complex Variables
courses.description: Complex functions, contour integration, power series, residues and poles, conformal mapping.

courses.name: Senior Seminar in Mathematics
courses.description: Seminar with student presentations, written projects, and problem solving. May be used for the capstone requirement.
courses.prerequisites: 12 hours of mathematics courses numbered 4000 or above

courses.name: Mathematics Problem Solving
courses.description: Creative advanced problem solving bringing together methods such as integration, probability and Euclidean geometry.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 4140 and another 4000 level Mathematics course, or instructor's consent

courses.name: Problems in Mathematics
courses.description: Problems in Mathematics

courses.name: Master's Thesis Research in Mathematics
courses.description: Students will be required to complete an independent project. Topics are chosen in consultation with a faculty advisor and are subject to departmental consent.  Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Topics in Algebra
courses.description: Advanced topics in algebra.

courses.name: Masters Project in Mathematics
courses.description: Masters Project in Mathematics

courses.name: Topics in Functional Analysis
courses.description: Topics in Functional Analysis

courses.name: Basic Algebra
courses.description: Accelerated problem solving course in linear and abstract algebra. Will prepare students for the algebra qualifying exam.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 4720, MATH 4920, or instructor's consent, or equivalentCorequisites: MATH 8220 and MATH 8250

courses.name: Basic Analysis
courses.description: Accelerated problem-solving course in advanced calculus and complex analysis.  Will prepare students for the analysis qualifying exam.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 4700, MATH 4900, MATH 4940, instructor's consent or equivalent

courses.name: Basic Topology and Geometry
courses.description: Topological spaces, differential manifolds, differential forms, integration of vector fields.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 4700, MATH 4900, MATH 4140, or instructor's consent, or equivalentCorequisites: MATH 8210 and MATH 8220

courses.name: Topics in Harmonic Analysis
courses.description: Topics in Harmonic Analysis

courses.name: Topics in Mathematical Physics
courses.description: Topics in Mathematical Physics

courses.name: Algebra I
courses.description: Theory of algebraic structures--groups, rings, fields, algebraic and transcendental extensions of fields.

courses.name: Algebra II
courses.description: Theory of modules, Galois theory and additional topics to be selected by the instructor.

courses.name: Theory of Functions of Real Variables I
courses.description: Properties of functions of one real variable. Lebesgue measure and integration on the line.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 4700 or MATH 7700 and MATH 4900 or MATH 7900, or equivalent

courses.name: Theory of Functions of Real Variables II
courses.description: Continuation of MATH 8420. General measure and integration theory.  Elements of the theory of Hilbert and Banach spaces, linear functions and linear operators.

courses.name: Complex Analysis I
courses.description: Rigorous introduction to the theory of functions of a complex variable.

courses.name: Complex Analysis II
courses.description: Analytic continuation, Riemann surfaces, entire and meromorphic functions, selected topics.

courses.name: Advanced Ordinary Differential Equations I
courses.description: Topics from existence and uniqueness theorems, plane autonomous systems, periodicity and boundedness of solutions of second order nonlinear equations, perturbation theory, Sturm-Liouville systems, behavior of solutions at singularities.

courses.name: Advanced Ordinary Differential Equations II
courses.description: Continuation of MATH 8440.

courses.name: Calculus of Variations I
courses.description: Development of necessary conditions and of sufficient conditions for nonparametric and parametric problems. Hamilton's principle, related topics.

courses.name: Partial Differential Equations I
courses.description: Fourier and integral transforms, first and second order partial differential equations, methods of characteristics, Laplace's equation, Direchlet and Neumann problems, Green's functions and maximum principles.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 4700 or MATH 7700 or instructor's consent required

courses.name: Partial Differential Equations II
courses.description: The Cauchy-Kovalevski theorem, the Lewy example, the heat operator, the wave operator, Sobolev spaces, local regularity of elliptic boundary value problems.

courses.name: Differential Geometry for Scientists and Engineers
courses.description: Tensors and multilinear forms. Connections, covariant differentiation, geodesics and curvature on Riemannian and pseudo Riemannian manifolds. Applications to special relativity and general relativity.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 4110 and some knowledge of Matrix Theory

courses.name: Mathematical Finance I
courses.description: (same as FINANC 8340). Financial instruments and derivative: stocks, bonds, futures option prices on interest rates, swaps, etc.  Mathematical models of stock price fluctuations.  Interest rates and options on interest rates.  Swaps.  Open markets and properties of stock option prices.  Stochastic models. Bionomial trees.  Continuous time stochastic modeling.  No arbitrage modeling.  European and American options.  BlackScholes model and differential equation, for the price of European option.  Exotic options.  Interest rate models.
courses.prerequisites: graduate standing in Mathematics.  Knowledge of elementary probability or instructor's consent

courses.name: Mathematical Finance II
courses.description: Diffusion Processes as models for stock price fluctuations. Contingent claims and arbitrage.  Mathematical analysis of risk neutral valuation of contingent claims.  Self-financing portfolios and hedging.  Hedging contingent claims.  Partial differential equations for valuation of derivative securities. Completeness of the markets and hedging.  Parity relations and delta hedging.  Several underlying assets.
courses.prerequisites: knowledge of advance probability/stochastic processes or instructor's consent

courses.name: Mathematical Methods of Risk Theory
courses.description: Probability aspects of Risk.  Claim number processes. Accumulated claim number processes. Retentions and Reserves. Mathematics of reinsurance.  Ruin probability calculations. Stability and dividends policy.  Utility as criterion of stability.  The problem of risk exchange.
courses.prerequisites: knowledge of elementary probability or instructor's consent

courses.name: Advanced Numerical Analysis
courses.description: Analysis and implementation of numerical algorithms selected from approximation theory, splines, quadrature, nonlinear systems, ordinary differential equations, and optimization.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 4700, MATH 4300 or equivalent, and MATH 4140

courses.name: Advanced Probability
courses.description: (same as STAT 9810). Measure theoretic probability theory. Characteristic functions; conditional probability and expectation; sums of independent random variables including strong law of large numbers and central limit problem.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 4320 or MATH 8220; or instructor's consent

courses.name: Topics of Geometry
courses.description: Topics of Geometry.

courses.name: Topology Seminar
courses.description: Topology Seminar

courses.name: Topics in Financial Mathematics and Insurance
courses.description: Topics in Financial Mathematics and Insurance

courses.name: Algebraic Geometry I
courses.description: Affine and projective varieties and schemes; nullstellensatz; Zariski topology, morphisms and rational maps; divisors and linear systems; topics from curves, surfaces, Grassmann varieties; commutative algebra and homological algebra as needed.

courses.name: Algebraic Geometry II
courses.description: Continuation of MATH 8615.

courses.name: Introduction to Algebraic Topology
courses.description: Development of singular homology theory; reference to other homology and cohomology theories. Introduction to homological algebra.

courses.name: Functional Analysis I
courses.description: Linear topological spaces, Banach spaces, Hilbert spaces. Operator theory, including the Hahn-Banach, uniform boundedness and closed graph theorems.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 4900 and instructor's consent or MATH 8420

courses.name: Functional Analysis II
courses.description: Topological vector spaces, duality theory, Banach algebras.

courses.name: Harmonic Analysis I
courses.description: An introduction to Fourier Analysis in one and higher Dimensions. Topics include Fourier Series, conjugate functions, Fourier transforms, distributions, interpolation, and maximal functions.

courses.name: Harmonic Analysis II
courses.description: Singular integrals, Littlewood-Paley theory, Hardy spaces, bounded mean oscillation, weighted norm inequalities, boundary value problems, and analysis on groups.

courses.name: Nonlinear Differential Equations
courses.description: Existence theorems; criteria for periodic solutions; boundedness of solutions; perturbation theory. Emphasizes second order equations.

courses.name: Advanced Mathematics for the Physical Sciences
courses.description: Study of selected topics in quantum and statistical mechanics. Schrodinger operators and their self-adjointness. Semi-classical methods and their application to estimation of eignevalues. Partition functions in many body problems and methods of estimation.

courses.name: Differentiable Manifolds and Riemannian Geometry
courses.description: Tensor product spaces and tensor fields on manifolds. Differentiation and integration of differential forms. Riemannian geometry and applications.

courses.name: General Topology I
courses.description: Introduction to axiomatic theory of general topology. Continuous functions and homeomorphisms. Convergence in abstract topological spaces. Compact and locally compact spaces. Connectedness. Metrizable spaces.

courses.name: Stochastic Processes
courses.description: (same as STAT 9820). Markov processes, martingales, orthogonal sequences, processes with independent and orthogonal increments, stationary, linear prediction.

courses.name: Topics in Applied Mathematics
courses.description: Selected topics in applied mathematics drawn from variety of areas: partial differential equations, tensor analysis, calculus of variations, asymptotic methods, integral equations, advanced theory of transforms and distributions, numerical analysis.

courses.name: Numerical Mathematics Seminar
courses.description: Numerical Mathematics Seminar

courses.name: Doctoral Dissertation Research in Mathematics
courses.description: Doctoral Dissertation Research in Mathematics. Graded on a S/U basis only.

courses.name: Algebra Seminar
courses.description: Algebra Seminar

courses.name: Functional Analysis Seminar
courses.description: Functional Analysis Seminar

courses.name: Harmonic Analysis Seminar
courses.description: Harmonic Analysis Seminar

courses.name: Mathematical Physics Seminar
courses.description: Mathematical Physics Seminar

courses.name: Topics in Topology
courses.description: Advanced topics in topology or topological algebra.

courses.name: Geometry Seminar
courses.description: Geometry Seminar

courses.description: Financial Mathematics Seminar
